CNN.com Student News Newsletter






 
Wednesday, April 11, 2007



 Watch and Learn 
Today's show begins with a report on Google's plan to raise awareness about a humanitarian crisis. Then, we explain why one state is trying to change how it casts its presidential ballots. And we find out why it's easy to read up on politicians in France.
We haven't reported on the recent controversy involving radio host Don Imus, but we want to hear your opinion. Do you think that CNN Student News should cover this story? 
Contact us at CNN.com/EDUCATION to let us know.

 Teaching life lessons in dollars and sense 
Fifteen-year-old Connor Lewis knows a thing or two about money. He pet-sits, mows yards and earns an allowance by doing chores; and he puts half of his earnings into a savings account. He comparison shops for video games and other items and doesn't buy them until he finds the cheapest price. But as teenage consumers go, Connor is the exception, not the rule.


 
CNN Student News is a 10-minute, commercial-free news program that airs on CNN Headline News at 3:12 a.m. EST as well as on CNN.com/EDUCATION. Created by a team of journalists and educators, the program provides the top stories of the day, segments that encourage student participation, and in-depth special reports. In addition, CNN Student News provides free curriculum at CNN.com/EDUCATION to accompany each program's content. CNN Student News, along with CNN Classroom Edition, is Turner Broadcasting's contribution to Cable in the Classroom.
